filedesc.publicationstmt:
Charlottesville: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; IATH
April 1998
filedesc.updatestmt:
The editors of the William Blake Archive are pleased to announce the publication of seven new electronic editions of Blake's illuminated books. They are: The [First] Book of Urizen Copy G, The Book of Los Copy A, The Book of Ahania Copy A, The Song of Los Copy B, America, a Prophecy Copy A, Europe, a Prophecy Copy E, and Visions of the Daughters of Albion Copy F.
We had announced Urizen Copy G as forthcoming two months ago, but formatting the double-columned text diplomatically in SGML for both Netscape and Internet Explorer proved more taxing and time consuming than anticipated. Such are the joys and tribulations of electronic publishing. Solving the problems there, though, ensured diplomatic transcriptions for Blake's other books with double-columned texts, The Book of Ahania and The Book of Los . Together, these three works are often referred to as Blake's Bible of Hell or, simply, the Urizen books. Urizen , of which there are only seven extant copies, was first produced in 1794, color printed to form Copies A, C, D, E (untraced), F, and J. It was printed again in 1795 to form Copy B, which was produced as part of a set of illuminated books printed on large paper, and then one last time in c. 1818 to form Copy G, which was produced in Blake's late printing and coloring style. The editors are currently working on Copies A, B, C, and F and expect to have them in the Archive by the end of the year. The Book of Ahania and The Book of Los exist in unique copies, with only a few proof impressions extant. They were printed in 1795 and executed in intaglio instead of in relief etching, the technique Blake normally used for his illuminated books. Although their texts are printed in intaglio, their frontispieces are beautifully color printed from the surface of the plates.
With The Song of Los , which consists of two parts entitled "Africa" and "Asia," we complete Blake's other series of illuminated books, sometimes known as the Continental Prophecies, begun in 1793 with America and continued in 1794 with Europe . The copy of The Song of Los included here is one of six extant; all were color printed in the same printing session in 1795.
With fourteen complete copies extant, America is not as rare as these other illuminated books, but Copy A, which was printed and colored in 1795 as part of Blake's large-paper set of books, is, along with Copies K, O, and M, one of only four colored copies—and it was the model for Copy K. Moreover, only it and Copy O have the last four lines on Plate 4, which was masked in the printing of the other copies. The Archive will include Copies M and O (c. 1807 and 1818) later this year.
Only nine copies of Europe are extant, and only two of those, Copies H and O (1795 and 1818), have Plate 3, the Preludium. The Archive will include both of these Copies by the end of the year. Copy E, included here, was lightly color printed on both sides of the paper in 1794 and joins Copy B, color printed more heavily on one side of the paper the same year.
Visions of the Daughters of Albion Copy F is an exquisitely beautiful copy, heavily color printed (especially its frontispiece) in c. 1794, and never before reproduced. It joins Copies C and J (both 1793), and will be joined later this year by Copies G and P (1795 and 1818).
All of these editions have newly edited texts; all images in the editions were scanned from either 4x5 or 8x10 transparencies, nearly all of which were made specifically for the Archive. Like our other editions, these are all SGML-encoded, fully searchable for both text and images and supported by the unique Inote and ImageSizer applications described in our previous updates.
The Archive now contains sixteen copies of ten illuminated books. In the coming months, we will be adding copies of All Religions are One , There is No Natural Religion , For the Sexes , Milton , and Jerusalem , along with copies of books already in the Archive but from different printings. Our goal is to have the entire illuminated canon online this year. In addition, work continues on the SGML edition of David V. Erdman's Complete Poetry and Prose of William Blake , which we anticipate releasing sometime this spring.

objinfo.objsize: ranging between 23.8 x 17.4 cm. and 23.1 x 16.3 cm. In Copies C-I, K, L, and R, the word "Preludium" (not "PRELUDIUM," pace Bentley page 91 and Erdman page 802) is printed from a small, separate copperplate, Plate e, 2.4 x 8.0 cm. In Copies A, B, and O, the word "Preludium" is omitted. In Copy M, "PRELUDIUM" (all capitals) is written by hand. Plate 11 is in the second of two states, with additional white line work in the lower left margin and just above the bottom edge of the plate. The first state is found only in Copy L. Plate 13 is in the second state, with a single tail on the snake, lower left.
objinfo.medium: Relief etching, with hand coloring and extensive white-line etching on Plates 1, 8, 10, 11, and 15. Most other plates bear at least touches of white-line etching/engraving.
objinfo.watermark: 1794/J Whatman The watermark appears only on Plates 4, 12, 16, and 17.

provenance.name: Morgan Library and Museum
provenance.price: Probably about 260, the price at which the dealer Bernard Quaritch advertised this copy in 1909.
provenance.note: Acquired from Blake by George Romney, probably in about 1795, and sold posthumously for Romney's son John, Christie's, 9 May 1834, lot 83, with Copy B of The Book of Urizen (£1.4s. to the dealer R. H. Evans); probably Isaac D'Israeli; sold anonymously, Hodgson auction, 14 Jan. 1904, lot 222 (£207 to the dealer Bernard Quaritch); sold by Quaritch to the Pierpont Morgan Library on 6 May 1909.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design embodies the destructiveness of warfare. In the middle distance is a stone wall with, on the right, the fragments of a top carved with classical motifs. A great gap appears to the left, and in this gap sits a giant winged figure. He is nude and muscular, with prominent knees and feet and both arms shackled and chained to the ground or to the remnants of the wall on which he squats or sits. His legs are drawn up in an extremely contracted posture, with his knees to his shoulders. His head is lowered and rests on his knees; his face is not pictured. His hair is long and curly. The contracted posture and lowered head suggest despair. He may be Albion's Angel, the representative of the establishment forces, or Orc, the personification of revolution. To the right is a family group, all nude. A woman, very probably a mother, sits on a fragment of the stone wall. Her hair is long and her face expresses a brooding fear, despair, or simply exhaustion. She holds in her lap a young child, probably male. He faces forward but perhaps looks up toward the woman. His (right?) knee is prominent. Another child, of uncertain gender, leans against the woman's left thigh and hip and hides his or her head below the woman's left arm. This figure's legs are crossed at the ankles. We see this figure from behind. On the ground below the woman is the haft of a broken sword, and further to the left is a dismounted cannon. The sky is dominated by dark clouds, perhaps of smoke. Touches of red on the edges of the clouds suggest a sunrise, sunset, or distant fire. A dark shadow cuts diagonally across the wall right of the woman, rising from left to right.

component.illusobjdesc: A dark shadow cuts diagonally across the wall right of the woman, rising from left to right.

A giant winged male sits or squats in a gap in a partly-destroyed wall. He is nude and muscular, with prominent knees and feet and both arms shackled and chained to the ground or to the remnants of the wall on which he squats or sits. His legs are drawn up in an extremely contracted posture, with his knees to his shoulders. His head is lowered and rests on his knees; his face is not pictured. His hair is long and curly. The contracted posture and lowered head suggest despair. He may be Albion's Angel, the representative of the establishment forces, or Orc, the personification of revolution.

Three nude figures, probably a mother and two children, huddle together. The woman sits on a fragment of the stone wall. Her hair is long and her face expresses a brooding fear. She holds in her lap a young child, probably male. He faces forward but perhaps looks up toward the woman. His (right?) knee is prominent. Another child, of uncertain gender, leans against the woman's left thigh and hip and hides his or her head below the woman's left arm. We see this figure from behind.

A nude female, probably the mother of the two children with her, sits on a fragment of the stone wall. Her hair is long and her face expresses a brooding fear, despair, or simply exhaustion. Her legs are crossed and her left(?) hand rests on her right knee. She holds in her lap a young child, probably male.
The woman holds in her lap a nude child, probably male. He faces forward, but may be looking up at the woman. We see only his face, right upper arm, and prominent (right?) knee.

A nude child of uncertain gender huddles with the woman. We see this figure from behind; his or her head is hidden by the woman's left arm. The figure's legs are crossed at the ankles; the buttocks are prominent.

The middle distance of the design is dominated by a stone wall, partly ruined. The top is decorated with classical motifs, perhaps including the egg and dart motif and palmettes. The family group, lower right, sits on a fragment of the decorated top of the wall.
The sky is dominated by clouds, perhaps of smoke. The touches of red on the edges of the clouds hint at a sunrise, sunset, or distant fires.
The wrists of the giant winged figure are shackled and chained.
The haft of a broken sword lies on the ground below the family group.
A dismounted cannon lies on the ground.
The fragment of the wall on which the giant winged figure sits looks like a plinth. This suggests that the figure is like a statue.

desc.objtitle:
AMERICA a PROPHECY,
Object 2 (Bentley 2, Erdman ii, Keynes ii)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The lowest part of the design is formed of male corpses stacked like cord wood. We see, on the first level of the stack, the tops of the heads and horizontally-extended arms of two rigid bodies lying prone. The next layer is a single rigid body, lying supine, with his legs extended to the right and his arms at his side. He faces up. Above him is a gowned woman with long hair, lying on top of him with her left leg drawn up and her right leg extended. She embraces the man around the neck with her left arm. Her face, seen in profile, touches the dead or dying man's face below her; she may be kissing him, trying to resuscitate him, or simply mourning over him. Her mouth is partly open. The dark sky above these figures contains a few diagonal white lines that may indicate rain or sleet descending from the clouds above. These large clouds bear the title, as though inscribed upon them, and six figures. On the left, a gowned woman with long hair sits with right leg extended before her and her left leg bent back behind her. She faces and hunches over to the left, apparently holding a book or tablet also being looked at or read by a gowned child, probably male, with curly hair. He stands before the woman and faces right, but is probably looking down at the book or tablet. At least his right arm is extended horizontally and may rest on the book or tablet. Behind the woman is another figure, perhaps nude and female, sitting with legs extended and her back leaning against the back of the woman. Although the scale of the figures is uncertain, this may be a child or young girl. Another group of three figures is on the right. An old, bearded man with long hair sits facing to the right. He wears a heavy gown and hunches over a book or tablet on his lap, at which he appears to be looking and perhaps reading. His posture is contracted, in contrast to the figure to the right—a nude female hovering in the air. We see her from behind; her posture is gracefully twisted. Her left arm is raised horizontally, her right arm at 135 degrees. The index finger on her right hand points upward. Her right leg is extended, her left drawn up. Her hair is in a bun. Behind the old man is a nude male, youthful and facing to the right although his body is turned to the left and leans against the back of the old man. His legs are crossed and he points upward and to the left with his right arm, hand, and extended index finger at an angle of 135 degrees. His left arm is bent and supported against the old man's back. Although these two nude figures are much smaller than the old man, they are probably not children but energetic representations of spiritual states unperceived, or ignored, by the old man. The two large figures with books or tablets have sometimes been identified as a sibyl and a prophet. Alternatively, the male may be a priest. The area at the bottom of the plate, below the imprint, contains washes that may indicate a landscape with low hills.

component.illusobjdesc: The area at the bottom of the plate, below the imprint, contains washes that may indicate a landscape with low hills.

The lowest part of the design is formed of male corpses stacked like cord wood. We see, on the first level of the stack, the tops of the heads and horizontally-extended arms of two rigid bodies lying prone.

A nude male lies supine on top of the prone corpses. His legs extend to the right and his one visible arm is at his side. He faces up. He is rigid and is probably dead or dying. His right foot is prominent and he may be holding something in his right hand.

Above the supine male is a gowned woman with long hair, lying on top of him with her left leg drawn up and her right leg extended. She embraces the man around the neck with her left arm. Her face, seen in profile, touches the dead or dying man's face below her; she may be kissing him, trying to resuscitate him, or simply mourning over him. Her mouth is partly open.

Left of the word "a" in the title inscription, a gowned woman with long hair sits with right leg extended before her and left leg bent back behind her. She faces and hunches over to the left, apparently holding with her extended left arm and hand, a book or tablet which she may be reading. She has sometimes been identified as a sibyl.
The seated woman holds and appears to read a book or tablet in her lap.

A gowned child with curly hair, probably male, stands before the seated woman. He faces right and apparently looks at and perhaps reads the tablet or book held by the woman. His right arm is raised horizontally and perhaps points to a passage in the book or tablet.

Behind the large seated woman is another figure, perhaps nude and female, sitting with legs extended and her back leaning against the back of the woman. Although the scale of the figures is uncertain, this may be a child or young girl. She turns her head toward us. Her right arm dangles at her side, and she may be pointing downward.

Right of the word "a" in the title inscription, an old, bearded man with long hair sits facing to the right. He wears a heavy gown and hunches over a book or tablet on his lap, at which he appears to be looking and perhaps reading. He may be a prophet or priest.
The seated old man holds and appears to read a book or tablet in his lap.

A nude female hovers in the air right of the old man. We see her from behind; her body is gracefully twisted, with her head facing to the left. Her left arm is raised horizontally, her right at 135 degrees. The index finger on her right hand points upward. Her right leg is extended, her left drawn up. Her hair is in a bun.

Behind the old man is a nude male, youthful and facing to the right although his body is turned to the left and leans against the back of the old man. His legs are crossed and he points upward and to the left with his right arm, hand, and extended index finger at an angle of 135 degrees. His left arm is bent and supported against the old man's back, against which he leans. A lock of his (long?) hair drifts to the left.

The dark and stormy sky above the woman lying on the corpses contains cloud outlines and diagonal white lines perhaps representing rain or sleet. The angle of the rain or sleet indicates a wind blowing from left to right.
The upper two-thirds of the plate contains cloud outlines against a dark, stormy sky. Both the title words and associated figures float seem to float on these clouds or hover before them.

lg.l: AMERICA
a
PROPHECY
LAMBETH
Printed by William Blake in the year 1793,

objnote.p: In Copies C-I, K, L, and R, the word "Preludium" (not "PRELUDIUM," pace Bentley page 91 and Erdman page 802) is printed from a small, separate copperplate, Plate e, 2.4 x 8.0 cm. In Copies A, B, and O, the word "Preludium" is omitted. In Copy M, "PRELUDIUM" (all capitals) is written by hand.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains considerable text, it appears as though the plate is treated as a single design extending across the top one third, down the left margin, and across the lower margin. A large tree, perhaps an oak, with arching branches dominates the top left of the design. The vegetation right of the large trunk may be a separate bush. Below and to the right of its trunk is an earthen bank (colored green, thereby indicating grass or perhaps moss) to which is shacked a nude, youthful male by both hands and feet. His arms are spread out horizontally on the rock, as if crucified; his legs are also spread apart. His torso and neck are twisted, perhaps in pain; he faces up. His mouth is open; he may be speaking or crying in pain. His hair is curly; he is probably Orc, the spirit of revolution here restrained. To the right are a nude male and female, both standing. The female, with legs spread apart, grasps her head with both hands, as if in mourning or despair. We do not see her face, but her upper torso is twisted to the left—toward the shackled youth. She may be Enitharmon, Orc's mother. Further to the right, the male stands with legs spread apart. His body faces us, but he turns his head to the left and may be looking at the shackled youth. His arms, with elbows bent, are raised over his head, with his hands raised, palms out, and the fingers of both hands spread apart. His hair is spiky or flame-like; his general expression is one of horror or grief. His mouth is slightly open; he may be speaking or crying out in sorrow. This may be Los, Orc's father. Alternatively, the couple has been identified as Adam and Eve, or as the "Dark virgin" and Urthona (another name for Los) mentioned on this plate (lines 12, 2). The roots of the tree descend through the left margin, perhaps taking on anthropomorphic shapes. At the end of the roots, in the far lower left corner of the plate, sits or squats a nude, youthful male in a severely contracted posture. His legs are drawn up, with his head resting on his knees. He faces forward, with a grim expression, and holds his crossed hands over his ankles. His hair is curly or flame-like. This may be another representation of Orc, as the personification of underground forces of revolution now enclosed but with the potential to break out. A reticulated worm, with six loops, fills the lower margin. The loops suggest (although they do not quite form) a spiral.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude, youthful male is shackled to an earthen bank by both hands and feet. A link or two of chains are also pictured. His arms and fingers are spread out horizontally on the rock, as if crucified; his legs are also spread apart. His torso and neck are twisted, perhaps in pain; he faces up. His mouth is open; he may be speaking or crying in pain. His hair is curly; he is probably Orc, the spirit of revolution here restrained.
The youth is shackled by his wrists and ankles to the earthen bank. A link or two of chains are also pictured.

A nude female, with long hair and legs spread apart, grasps her head with both hands, as if in mourning or despair. We do not see her face, but her upper torso is twisted to the left—toward the shackled youth. She may be Enitharmon, Orc's mother, but she has also been identified as the "Dark virgin" named on the plate (line 12).

A nude male stands with legs spread apart. His body faces us, but his head is turned to the left and may be looking at the shackled youth. His arms, with elbows bent, are raised over his head, with his hands raised, palms out, and the fingers of both hands spread apart. His hair is curly or flame-like; his general expression is one of horror or grief. His mouth is slightly open; he may be speaking or crying out in sorrow. This may be Los, Orc's father, but he has also been identified as Urthona (another name for Los, mentioned on this plate in lines 2 and 17) and as Adam.

In the far lower left corner of the plate sits or squats a nude, youthful male in a severely contracted posture. His legs are drawn up, with his head resting on his knees. He faces forward, with a grim expression, and holds his crossed hands over his ankles. His hair is spiky or flame-like. This may be another representation of Orc, as the personification of underground forces of revolution now enclosed but with the potential to break out.
The youth sits in a contracted posture on a small mound.
A large, reticulated worm fills the lower margin. Its six loops suggest, but do not quite form, a spiral.

A large tree, perhaps an oak, dominates the top left quarter of the plate. Its branches arch over to the right; a few leaves appear on the descending branches far right. Its roots descend down the left margin of the plate; some have anthropomorphic shapes, particularly left of lines 11-16 of the text.
The vegetation right of the large trunk of the tree may be a separate, leafy plant.
The green coloring of the ground below the shackled figure and extending to the right suggests grass or perhaps moss.
Narrow shadows appear below the feet of the standing man and woman.
The youthful male is shackled to an earthen bank.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The spaces between lines of text are filled with vegetative motifs, including vines. Some bear leaves, most prominently right of lines 16-17, and some may bear flowers. Vines right of lines 2 and 6 form loops. The vine left of lines 20- 21 forms a small spiral.

component.illusobjdesc: The spaces between lines of text are filled with vegetative motifs, including vines. Some bear leaves, most prominently right of lines 16-17, and some may bear flowers. Vines right of lines 2 and 6 form loops. The vine left of lines 20-21 forms a small spiral.

l.note: In Copies C-I, K, L, and R, the word "Preludium" (not "PRELUDIUM," pace Bentley page 91 and Erdman page 802) is printed from a small, separate copperplate, Plate e, 2.4 x 8.0 cm. In Copies A, B, and O, the word "Preludium" is omitted. In Copy M, "PRELUDIUM" (all capitals) is written by hand.

lg.l: The shadowy daughter of Urthona stood before red Orc,
When fourteen suns had faintly journey'd o'er his dark abode;
His food she brought in iron baskets, his drink in cups of iron;
Crown'd with a helmet & dark hair the nameless female stood;
A quiver with its burning stores, a bow like that of night,
When pestilence is shot from heaven; no other arms she need:
Invulnerable tho' naked, save where clouds roll round her loins,
Their awful folds in the dark air; silent she stood as night;
For never from her iron tongue could voice or sound arise;
But dumb till that dread day when Orc assay'd his fierce embra In Copy A, the characters "ce." that would complete the word "embrace" at the end of line 11 are obscured.
Dark virgin; said the hairy youth. thy father stern abhorr'd;
Rivets my tenfold chains while still on high my spirit soars;
Sometimes an eagle screaming in the sky, sometimes a lion,
Stalking upon the mountains, & sometimes a whale I lash
The raging fathomless abyss, anon a serpent folding
Around the pillars of Urthona, and round thy dark limbs,
On the Canadian wilds I fold, feeble my spirit folds.
For chaind beneath I rend these caverns; when thou bringest food
I howl my joy: and my red eyes seek to behold thy face
In vain! these clouds roll to & fro, & hide thee from my sight.

objnote.p: Lines 19-23 appear only in Copies A, N-Q. In Copies B-F, H-M, R, and a, these five lines were deleted by being masked during printing; in Copy G, they were erased after printing (Bentley page 94).

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although containing a good deal of text, the plate is treated almost as a full-page design, with pictorial motifs filling the lower third of the plate and continuing up the left margin. In the lower margin, a muscular nude youth with curly, flame- like hair seems to be rising out of the ground. His right knee and foot are prominent; his hands are placed on the ground and his arms, bent sharply at the elbows, seem to be pushing him upward. He looks up and to the right. This is probably Orc. To the left are a good many roots, as though we could see below the surface of the earth. Above these roots is a large plant growing up the left margin. It bears two large leaves and a long branch that terminates in a grain tassel. To the left of this plant is a vine that forms a long, vertical spiral. There are a few small plants and tufts of grass right of the nude male and left and right of the large plant. Colors indicating radiance emanate from the lower right. These suggest a sunrise or sunset, with its beams of light extending upward through the text. The yellow, disc-like area from which the radiance emanates suggests the sun. Blue washes along the top margin of the plate suggest clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: Colors indicating radiance emanate from the lower right. These suggest a sunrise or sunset, with its beams of light extending upward through the text.
The yellow area from which the radiance emanates might be the sun on the horizon.
Blue washes along the top margin of the plate suggest clouds.
The figure rises from a small depression (suggestive of a grave?) in a mound of earth, or small hill, or side of a cliff.

A muscular nude youth with flame-like hair seems to be rising out of the ground. His right knee and foot are prominent; his hands are placed on the ground and his arms, bent sharply at the elbows, seem to be pushing him upward. He looks up and to the right. This is probably Orc.
The surface of the earth is indicated by a few small plants with leaves and perhaps grass, far right. There are slight indications of grass or small plants just right of the large plant on the left.

A large plant dominates the left margin of the plate. We see its roots beneath the surface of the earth, two large leaves, and a long branch growing up the left margin that terminates in a grain tassel. A spiral vine also grows up the left margin, with one loop around the main stem of the plant.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The spaces between lines of text and the margins are filled with vegetative motifs. Some of these vines bear leaves; large vines left of lines 3-6 and 8-16 include loops. On top of the second of these vine, just above the first word in line 8, is a small seated figure, bending forward and facing to the right with at least one leg extended to the right and one arm possibly reaching toward the foot. Another small figure seems to be hovering above "have" in the same line of text, facing left, one arm raised horizontally and one raised vertically, and legs spread apart. This figure may be holding the vine to the left. A vine growing from the first letter of the last word in line 8 ("go") includes two loops suggestive of a spiral. A bird with extended wings flies at the end of line 16; small birds fly above "will" (line 8) and "me" (line 10). The last word of line 18 grows into a vine with two leaves; most of this vine turns to the left and underscores line 18. Loopy vines appear as letter extensions left of lines 19-21.

component.illusobjdesc: A small figure sits on the vine above the first word of line 8 of the text. He or she faces to the right, bending forward with at least one leg extended and one arm possibly reaching toward the foot.
A small figure hovers above "have" in line 8 of the text. He or she faces left, one arm raised horizontally and one vertically, and legs spread apart. The figure may be holding the vine to the left.

The spaces between and left of lines of text are filled with vegetative motifs. Some of these vines bear leaves; a large vine left of lines 8-11 includes a loop. A vine growing from the first letter of the last word in line 8 ("go") includes two loops suggestive of a spiral.
A bird with extended wings flies at the end of line 15. Smaller birds fly above "will" (line 8) and "me" (line 10).
The last word of line 18 grows into a vine with two leaves; most of this vine turns to the left and underlines the last line of text.
Loopy vines appear as letter extensions left of lines 19-21.

lg.l: Silent as despairing love. and strong as jealousy.
The hairy shoulders rend the links, free are the wrists of fire;
Round the terrific loins he siez'd the panting struggling womb;
It joy'd: she put aside her clouds & smiled her first-born smile;
As when a black cloud shews its light'nings to the silent deep.
Soon as she saw the terrible boy then burst the virgin cry.
I know thee, I have found thee, & I will not let thee go;
Thou art the image of God who dwells in darkness of Africa:
And thou art fall'n to give me life in regions of dark death.
On my American plains I feel the struggling afflictions
Endur'd by roots that writhe their arms into the nether deep:
I see a serpent in Canada, who courts me to his love;
In Mexico an Eagle, and a Lion in Peru;
I see a Whale in the South-sea, drinking my soul away.
O what limb rending pains I feel, thy fire & my frost
Mingle in howling pains, in furrows by thy lightnings rent;
This is eternal death; and this the torment long foretold.

The stern Bard ceas'd, asham'd of his own song; enrag'd he swung Lines 19-23 appear only in Copies A, N-Q. In Copies F-F, H-M, R, and a, these five lines were deleted by being masked during printing; in Copy G, the were erased after printing (Bentley page 94).
His harp aloft sounding, then dash'd its shining frame against
A ruin'd pillar in glittring fragments; silent he turn'd away
And wander'd down the vales of Kent in sick & drear la-
-mentings.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The area above the text bearing the heading ("A / PROPHECY") apparently represents the sky. Six birds fly on extended wings; three of these seem to be soaring upwards. Upper left, a nude, muscular male also seems to be ascending. He has apparently broken free of the chains that still dangle from his wrists. His right arm is at his side; his left arm is bent back over his left shoulder. His left leg is bent behind him; we see only the left ankle and foot. His hair may be curly. He faces forward with his head tilted up. This may be another representation of Orc or, more generally, humanity freed from its chains by revolution. The words of the heading are integrated into vegetative design motifs, including several vines with leaves, spiraling vines growing from the first and last letters of "PROPHECY" (line 3), and grain stems and tassels growing from the first word of the heading ("A") (line 2). Background washes hint at clouds tinged with rose by the fires in the design below or by a sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Background washes hint at clouds tinged with rose by the fires in the design below or by a sunrise or sunset.

A bird flies on extended wings just left of the first letter of "PROPHECY" in the heading (line 3). Another bird flies above the upper loop of the first letter of the first word ("The") of the body of the text (line 4).

Four birds fly on extended wings: a rising bird above the "C" of "PROPHECY" in the heading (line 3), another rising bird below this same letter, a rising bird right of the descender of the final letter of "PROPHECY," and, just above this bird, a smaller bird flying horizontally. All but the last of these birds have forked tails.

The first diagonal of "A" in the heading (line 2) grows at its lower end into a vine terminated by either leaves or a flower with a prominent stamen. Descending from the middle of the letter is an intertwined vine with small flowers. The second diagonal of "A" in the heading grows at its lower end into arching grain stems with tassels.
The first letter of "PROPHECY" in the heading (line 3) grows into a spiral vine, upper left. Another vine, with ivy-like leaves and perhaps flowers, is intertwined with the letter.
The third letter of "PROPHECY" in the heading (line 3) grows into a spiral vine. The next letter grows, lower left, into a vine with one loop.
The top of "H" in "PROPHECY" (line 3) grows into a vine with one loop. The vine terminates either in some leaves or a flower with a prominent stamen.
The descender of the last letter of "PROPHECY" in the heading (line 3) grows into a vine running horizontally below the word. The vine has three loops, suggesting a spiral.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Between lines 8 and 9 of the text, a hovering nude male, perhaps an apocalyptic angel of the last trump, holds with both hands and blows into a large trumpet. We see him from behind; his hair is long and streams to the left, as though blown by a wind. Issuing from the mouth of the trumpet is a great blast of fire that turns upward in the left margin of the plate. Below, and evidently part of the same design, are further flames and smoke, including a line of fire between lines 15 and 17 of the text. In the lower left corner of the plate is a nude family group fleeing from the fires above and behind them. The male (father?) is in the middle; he holds the hand of a young boy on the left. He strides forward with his left leg and looks back at the flames. His hair may be curly. The woman (mother?) strides forward with her right leg, also turns back to the flames, and raises her left arm over her head. The fingers of her left hand are spread apart. The boy on the left strides forward with his left leg, also seems to be looking back, and raises his right arm over his head. All three figures stride over a small mound of earth or hill.

On the right of the family group is a nude woman, perhaps the mother. She strides forward with her right leg, fleeing the flames above and behind her. Her head is turned back and to the left; her left arm is raised vertically, with the fingers of her left hand spread apart. Her hair may be drawn into a bun.

Flames issue from the trumpet blown by the figure between lines 8 and 9 of the text and extend upward in the left margin. The family group in the lower left corner of the plate runs over a mound of earth or low hill. The green coloring suggests grass. Shadows extend from the figures' feet.

lg.l: The Guardian Prince of Albion burns in his nightly tent,
Sullen fires across the Atlantic glow to America's shore:
Piercing the souls of warlike men, who rise in silent night,
Washington, Franklin, Paine & Warren, Gates, Hancock & Green;
Meet on the coast glowing with blood from Albions fiery Prince.
Washington spoke; Friends of America look over the Atlantic sea;
A bended bow is lifted in heaven, & a heavy iron chain
Descends link by link from Albions cliffs across the sea to bind
Brothers & sons of America, till our faces pale and yellow;
Heads deprest, voices weak, eyes downcast, hands work-bruis'd,
Feet bleeding on the sultry sands, and the furrows of the whip
Descend to generations that in future times forget.------
sea
The strong voice ceas'd; for a terrible blast swept over the heaving
The eastern cloud rent; on his cliffs stood Albions wrathful Prince
A dragon form clashing his scales at midnight he arose,
And flam'd red meteors round the land of Albion beneath
His voice, his locks, his awful shoulders, and his glowing eyes,

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains considerable text, it would appear that the pictorial image is treated as a full-plate design. At top right, just below line 2, is a winged dragon of a type traditionally called a wyvern. The creature is apparently flying through the air. It faces to the left, with a coiled or spiral tail with one loop on the right. Its skin looks scaly and its face is somewhat dog-like, with a partly opened mouth and large teeth. The top of its head bears a crest. Its front paws look almost like human hands. Below and to the left of its left paw is a jagged line, perhaps representing a bolt of lightning. Further to the left, and descending into the left margin, is an old man. His gown forms a long, snake-like tail behind him, rather like the wyvern's tail. He has a long beard and long hair. His right arm is at his side, but we can see that, with his right hand, he grasps a large book or tablet. His left arm reaches downward and he holds in his left hand a scepter or spear with a fleur-de-lis point. This figure may be Albion's Angel or Urizen (twice referred to in the text) with his book of laws. Below this descending figure is another jagged line, perhaps representing lightning, and several cloud outlines extending to the right margin above the last two lines of text. Red wash suggests a sunrise or sunset just above the clouds and below the words "not light" in line 12. Below these billowing clouds, in the plate's lower margin, is a landscape that includes three figures, probably a family group of father, mother, and child. Lower left is the trunk of a large tree, fallen on the ground to the left. On the right, behind the figure group, is another fallen tree with a heavy limb extending upward and toward the right margin. The male is the left-most figure in the group, lower right. He is nude and squats or kneels on the ground, with his upper body bent forward. Both arms are raised and bent at the elbows; he grasps his head with both hands. This gesture, and his crude facial features, express despair or terror. To the right is a crouching female. She may be gowned or nude. Her left knee and foot are prominent. She turns her head to the right; we cannot see her face because it is covered by the head of a child of uncertain gender she embraces. This child is standing and may be gowned, although we can see little of this figure beyond the left side of his or her head and the left leg. These two figures seem to be seeking protection in each other's arms.

component.illusobjdesc: Red wash suggests a sunrise or sunset just above the clouds and below the words "not light" in line 12.

In the plate's lower margin is a landscape that includes three figures, probably a family group of father, mother, and child.

The male (perhaps the father) is the left-most figure in the family group, lower right. He is nude and squats or kneels on the ground, with his upper body bent slightly forward and his face turned partly downward. Both arms are raised and bent at the elbows; he grasps his head with both hands. This gesture, and his crude facial features, express despair or terror.

The crouching female in the family group, lower right, is probably the mother. She may be gowned or nude. Her left knee and foot are prominent. She turns her head to the right; we cannot see her face because it is covered by the head of a child of uncertain gender she embraces.
The woman embraces a child of uncertain gender. This child is standing and may be gowned, although we can see little of this figure beyond the left side of his or her head and the left leg.
A jagged line below and to the left of the dragon's left paw may represent lightning.
A jagged line below the descending old man may represent lightning.
The sky is filled with the outlines of clouds.

The trunk of a large, fallen tree dominates the landscape, lower left. One short branch and at least two roots are pictured. Another fallen tree appears behind the figures, lower right. One heavy branch extends upward and to the right margin.

lg.l: Appear to the Americans upon the cloudy night.
Solemn heave the Atlantic waves between the gloomy nations
Swelling. belching from its deeps red clouds & raging fires,
Albion is sick. America faints! enrag'd the Zenith grew,
As human blood shooting its veins all round the orbed heaven
Red rose the clouds from the Atlantic in vast wheels of blood
And in the red clouds rose a Wonder o'er the Atlantic sea;
Intense! naked! a Human fire fierce glowing, as the wedge
Of iron heated in the furnace; his terrible limbs were fire
With myriads of cloudy terrors banners dark & towers
Surrounded; heat but not light went thro' the murky atmo-
-sphere

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although containing considerable text, the plate is treated as a full-plate design with six nude and muscular male figures. Top left is a man hovering horizontally in the air in front of a cloud. His left leg extends back and up behind him; his left arm extends out to the right and he points in that direction with his left index finger. In his right hand he holds large scales (or, more precisely, a pair of balances), perhaps to be associated with the Day of Judgement. This figure may be a personification of Justice. He has long hair and looks up and to the right at the pair of figures to his right. The lower man in this pair seems to be standing, with one leg bent and one extended, on the outline of the cloud. He is bent over, with his face hidden. His hair is curly. With both arms bent at the elbows and extended over his head he carries on his back another nude male. This figure, in an extremely contracted posture, has his arms clasped behind his back, both legs drawn up, and his head and upper body bent over so that his head seems to touch his groin or left thigh. Perhaps we are to think that the man holding this figure is about to cast him into the abyss. Further to the right, but still above the text area, is another nude figure with long hair that forms loops. In spite of this feature, the musculature suggests a male. We see him from behind, floating vertically in the air, with legs slightly spread. His left arm is raised, his right is lowered, but he grasps with both hands a giant sword with flames emanating from its edge and trailing off to the right, as though blown by a wind. The arm position suggests that he may be sheathing the sword, although no sheath is clearly pictured. This figure, perhaps another personification of Justice, looks to the right. Below the text are large tongues of flame with accompanying smoke, perhaps suggesting hell. Just above or within these fires are two more nude males. The figure on the left hovers horizontally in the air, although he may be falling into the flames below. His hair is curly. His knees are drawn up toward his torso and he grasps the back of his head with both hands and faces down. This gesture suggests despair. To the right is a male falling head-first. His knees are sharply bent and he too seems to grasp his head with both hands. Around him circles a giant snake, with open mouth and a forked tongue. Below the human figure, the snake's tail forms a spiral into which the man may be falling. The skin of the snake is scaly.

lg.l: Albions Angel stood beside the Stone
of night, and saw
The terror like a comet, or more like the
planet red
That once inclos'd the terrible wandering comets in its sphere.
Then Mars thou wast our center, & the planets three flew round
Thy crimson disk; so e'er the Sun was rent from thy red sphere;
The Spectre glowd his horrid length staining the temple long
With beams of blood; & thus a voice came forth, and shook the
temple

illustration.illusobjdesc: A youthful, muscular, nude male sits on the ground. His legs are bent at the knees, with thighs spread apart (clearly revealing his genitals) and his feet below the center of his body. His arms are behind him, apparently with hands resting on the ground for support (we see only his right hand on the ground). His hair is curly. His body is slightly twisted as he faces up and to the right. He may be in the act of rising from the ground. Behind are clouds; the earth below may be a small hill or mound covered with grass or moss. Below his right foot and on the right are several leaves, perhaps oak or grape leaves. A vine-like plant with leaves and perhaps flowers decorates the right side of the mound and descends into the right margin of the text. There may also be a few tufts of grass on the far right side of the mound. On the left is a skull, facing skyward. This motif suggests that the male may be sitting on a grave—perhaps his own, from which he is rising. Far left are a few tufts of grass and another vine dangling down the left margin of the text; it bears large leaves (perhaps grape).

lg.l: The morning comes, the night decays, the watchmen leave
their stations;
The grave is burst, the spices shed, the linen wrapped up;
The bones of death, the cov'ring clay, the sinews shrunk & dry'd.
Reviving shake. inspiring move, breathing! awakening!
Spring like redeemed captives when their bonds & bars are burst;
Let the slave grinding at the mill, run out into the field;
Let him look up into the heavens & laugh in the bright air;
Let the inchained soul shut up in darkness and in sighing,
Whose face has never seen a smile in thirty weary years;
Rise and look out, his chains are loose, his dungeon doors are open.
And let his wife and children return from the opressors scourge;
They look behind at every step & believe it is a dream.
Singing. The Sun has left his blackness, & has found a fresher morning
And the fair Moon rejoices in the clear & cloudless night;
For Empire is no more, and now the Lion & Wolf shall cease.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains seven lines of text, the pictorial image is treated as a full-plate design. The landscape below the text includes, on the left, a large tree, perhaps a birch or willow, growing up the left margin. Its long, slender branches and leaves (or perhaps catkins) arch over the text. Three birds, two with long, forked tails, are perched on the branches. Three other birds fly in the air, plus a winged insect (perhaps a moth or butterfly). The landscape below includes grass and two large leaves. The leaf on the left, near the tree, has a vine-like stem; this may be a grape vine. The leaf in the lower right corner might be either a grape or oak leaf. Lying on the grass is a ram, facing right, apparently asleep. A young boy or male child rests his arms and head on the ram's back; his feet (or at least one foot) can be seen right of the ram's head. This boy has curly hair and is probably also sleeping. Below the ram, another youth, but of uncertain gender, is stretched on the grass, perhaps asleep. We see this nude figure from behind. The figure's left leg is extended, the right bent at the knee. The figure's head lies on his or her right arm; we see only the top of the figure's head and long hair. Water appears below the figures, just above the bottom margin of the plate; this may be a river or lake. The coloring of the sky suggests a sunrise or sunset behind the sheep. Radiant beams of light extend upward to the branches above the text. This gentle, pastoral scene contrasts sharply with the apocalyptic tone of the text on the plate.

lg.l: In thunders ends the voice. Then Albions Angel wrathful burnt
Beside the Stone of Night; and like the Eternal Lions howl
In famine & war, reply'd. Art thou not Orc, who serpent-form'd
Stands at the gate of Enitharmon to devour her children;
Blasphemous Demon, Antichrist, hater of Dignities;
Lover of wild rebellion. and transgresser of Gods Law;
Why dost thou come to Angels eyes in this terrific form?

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains a good deal of text, Blake treated the pictorial image as a full-plate design. Above, an old, bearded, and gowned man sits among clouds. His long hair cascades over his left shoulder. He faces forward, but looks slightly to the left. His arms are raised horizontally; his hands seem to be holding the clouds on which they rest, palms down. His right leg is drawn up toward his chest in a contracted posture; the right knee and foot are prominent. His left leg is not pictured. The lines below his right foot may be a fold of his garment, but possibly a sandal. This figure is very probably Urizen. At the bottom of the plate is a dark and stormy sea with waves. The text panel is shaped in such a way as to suggest a cloud between the upper and lower parts of the design, although in this copy the blue tinting suggests that this might be a break between clouds. The design, particularly the figure, offers a contrasting parallel to the design on plate 12.

His right leg is drawn up toward his chest in a contracted posture; the right knee and foot are prominent. His left leg is not pictured. The lines below his right foot may be a fold of his garment, but possibly a sandal. This is probably Urizen.
Below the text is a dark and stormy sea with waves.

Dense clouds form both the surface on which the figure sits and his background. The text panel is shaped like a cloud, although the blue tinting in this copy suggests that it might be a break between clouds.
A jagged line just below "like silver" in the last line of text suggests a bolt of lightning over the sea.

lg.l: The terror answerd; I am Orc, wreath'd round the accursed tree:
The times are ended; shadows pass the morning gins to break;
The fiery joy, that Urizen perverted to ten commands,
What night he led the starry hosts thro' the wide wilderness;
That stony law I stamp to dust: and scatter religion abroad
To the four winds as a torn book, & none shall gather the leaves;
But they shall rot on desart sands, & consume in bottomless deeps,
To make the desarts blossom, & the deeps shrink to their fountains,
And to renew the fiery joy, and burst the stony roof.
That pale religious letchery, seeking Virginity,
May find it in a harlot, and in coarse-clad honesty
The undefil'd tho' ravish'd in her cradle night and morn:
For every thing that lives is holy, life delights in life;
Because the soul of sweet delight can never be defil'd.
Fires inwrap the earthly globe, yet man is not consumd;
Amidst the lustful fires he walks; his feet become like brass,
His knees and thighs like silver, & his breast and head like gold.

objnote.p: Plate 11 is in the second of two states, with additional white line work in the lower left margin and just above the bottom edge of the plate. The first state is found only in Copy L.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text, the dense white-line hatching represents grain stems and tassels. Below one of the two arching clusters of grain is a nude infant or child, probably male, lying supine on the ground. His arms are at his side and his body is rigid; he may be dead. Right and left of the child are two plants with large leaves and vine-like tendrils. At least the plant on the right bears two flowers. Both plants have been identified as poppies. The white-line crosshatching extending up the left margin of the text might represent the clouds of an approaching storm, smoke, the sky, or simply the chaos of the material world. Gray washes through the text area suggest clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude infant or child, probably male, lies supine on the ground below arching grain stems. His arms are at his side and his body is rigid; he may be dead.
Below the text, the dense white-line hatching represents grain stems and tassels. Two prominent clusters of stems arch over to the left.

Right and left of the child are two plants with large leaves and vine-like tendrils. At least the plant on the right bears two flowers and a loop in at least one stem. Both plants have been identified as poppies.
The white-line crosshatching extending up the left margin of the text might represent the clouds of an approaching storm, smoke, the sky, or simply the chaos of the material world.
Gray washes through the text area suggest clouds.
The dark area in the lower right corner of the plate may be a shadow.

The most prominent is the first letter of the first word in line 2, the last letter of "round" in line 8, and the middle letter of the second "the" in line 9. The right margin of the text is filled with vines, a few bearing leaves.

The final letter of "round," line 8 of the text, has a vine trailing from its top. A vine sprouts from the middle letter of "the," second word from the end of line 9.
The right margin of the text is filled with vines, a few bearing leaves. One is looped.

lg.l: Sound! sound! my loud war-trumpets & alarm my Thirteen Angels,
Loud howls the eternal Wolf! the eternal Lion lashes his tail!
America is darkned; and my punishing Demons terrified
Crouch howling before their caverns deep like skins dry'd in the wind
They cannot smite the wheat, nor quench the fatness of the earth,
They cannot smite with sorrows; nor subdue the plow and spade,
They cannot wall the city, nor moat round the castle of princes,
They cannot bring the stubbed oak to overgrow the hills
For terrible men stand on the shores, & in their robes I see
Children take shelter from the lightnings, there stands Washington
And Paine and Warren with their foreheads reard toward the east
But clouds obscure my aged sight. A vision from afar!
Sound! sound! my loud war-trumpets & alarm my thirteen Angels:
Ah vision from afar! Ah rebel form that rent the ancient

Heavens! Eternal Viper self-renew'd, rolling in clouds Blake etched an exclamation mark after "Heavens," but in Copy A the vertical stroke was not inked, except for a bottom and top edge, and prints mostly as a blind embossment.
I see thee in thick clouds and darkness on America's shore.
Writhing in pangs of abhorred birth; red flames the crest rebellious
And eyes of death; the harlot womb oft opened in vain
Heaves in enormous circles, now the times are return'd upon thee,
Devourer of thy parent, now thy unutterable torment renews.
Sound! sound! my loud war trumpets & alarm my thirteen Angels.
Ah terrible birth! a young one bursting! where is the weeping mouth? In Copy A, the question mark following "mouth" at the end of the line is partially obscured by poor printing at the plate border.
And where the mothers milk? instead those ever-hissing jaws
And parched lips drop with fresh gore; now roll thou in the clouds
Thy mother lays her length outstretch'd upon the shore beneath.
Sound! sound! my loud war-trumpets & alarm my thirteen Angels!
Loud howls the eternal Wolf: the eternal Lion lashes his tail!

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains considerable text, the pictorial image is treated as a full-plate design. Below the text, a nude, muscular, youthful male rises among flames. His hair is curly and snake-like; his mouth is open. He faces forward, but looks slightly to the left. His left leg is bent at the knee, as though he were stepping up and rising; his right leg is covered by flames. This figure is very probably Orc, the spirit of revolution. His arms are raised horizontally, with his hands resting on the flames. The visible fingers of both hands are spread apart; both hands are poised as though the man was calling forth the flames that surround him. One tongue of flame, added in this copy with water color and perhaps pen and ink, extends over his torso from left to right and rises above his left shoulder. These flames (of hell?) and accompanying smoke extend up the left margin almost to the top of the plate and appear in the spaces between the text, particularly between lines 5 and 6. The design offers a contrasting parallel to the design on plate 10.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude, muscular, youthful male rises among flames. His hair is curly and snake-like; his mouth is open. He faces forward, but looks slightly to the left. His left leg is bent at the knee, as though he were stepping up and rising; his right leg is covered by flames. This figure is very probably Orc, the spirit of revolution. His arms are raised horizontally, with his hands resting on the flames. The visible fingers of both hands are spread apart; both hands are poised as though the man was calling forth the flames that emanate from beneath his prominent left foot.

The figure is surrounded by flames (of hell?) and smoke. The fires climb almost to the top of the plate along the left margin and appear in the upper right corner, between lines 5 and 6 of the text, and between lines 11 and 12 on the right. One tongue of fire, added in this copy with water color and perhaps pen and ink, extends diagonally across the figure's torso and rises above his left shoulder.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vines appear at the end of lines 7 and 9 of the text. The higher vine includes three loops. Extensions of letters at the beginning of lines 4 and 11 form vine-like tendrils. The extension of the "y" in the first word of line 11 forms a loop. A loopy vine extends from the second letter of "those" (line 6); the extensions of the first letter of "Golden" (line 8) are also vine-like.

Vines appear at the end of lines 7 and 9 of the text. The higher vine includes three loops. The extensions of the first letter of "Golden" (line 8) are also vine-like.

lg.l: Thus wept the Angel voice & as he wept the terrible blasts
Of trumpets, blew a loud alarm across the Atlantic deep.
No trumpets answer; no reply of clarions or of fifes,
Silent the Colonies remain and refuse the loud alarm.
On those vast shady hills between America & Albions shore;
Now barr'd out by the Atlantic sea: call'd Atlantean hills;
Because from their bright summits you may pass to the Golden world
An ancient palace, archetype of mighty Emperies,
Rears its immortal pinnacles, built in the forest of God
By Ariston the king of beauty for his stolen bride,
Here on their magic seats the thirteen Angels sat perturb'd
For clouds from the Atlantic hover o'er the solemn roof,

objnote.p: The plate is in the second state of two, with one tail on the snake, lower left.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains considerable text, the pictorial image is treated as a full page design. Given the presence of stars and a crescent moon, this is a night scene. The sky is filled with clouds and the text panel is also shaped like a cloud. High in the sky, but below line 4, a giant swan flies on extended wings to the right. A youthful nude male rides on his back. The figure's legs are spread apart and dangle on each side of the swan's back just in front of its wings. The youth's is blown to the left by the onward flight of the bird. The figure looks back to the left, away from the direction of flight, and braces himself with his right arm. His left arm is raised horizontally and he holds in his left hand a rein attached to the swan's beak. This figure has sometimes been identified as Boston's Angel, although the reason for this may be nothing more than the fact that he is named in the text immediately above the figure (line 4). To the right of the swan are four much smaller birds, all flying on extended wings. The largest of these has a forked tail. Below, and to the left of the text panel, are seven or eight stars; seven of them may be a constellation, the Pleiades. Below the text, but still in the night sky, are two more flying birds and, on the right, the crescent moon and a single star (or perhaps the planet Venus). The earth appears only along the lower margin; the green coloring indicates grass and a small plant in the lower right corner. Three nude children ride on the back of a snake. The front-most child, perhaps a girl with long hair, holds a pair of reins in her left hand that extends to the snake's open mouth. It's forked tongue is prominent and at least one horn extends back from its head. The second child, further to the left, appears to be a male. He braces himself with his left arm, perhaps holding on to the snake with his left hand, and reaches back with his right arm to hold hands with the very young child or infant nearest the snake's tail. This child reaches up, perhaps with both hands, but faces to the right and may be looking down. The right-most child has her legs together; the others have their legs spread on each side of the snake (although we see only their right legs). The snake's body forms a loop left of the children and terminates in two more loops and a single tail (two were eliminated in this, the second state of the plate).

component.illusobjdesc: Most of the design consists of the sky filled with clouds. The text panel is also shaped as a cloud. Given the presence of stars and a crescent moon, this would appear to be a night scene.

A pair of reins extends from the snake's mouth to the left hand of the child nearest the snake's head.

A single star (or perhaps the planet Venus) appears in the night sky just above the snake's head.
A crescent moon appears in the night sky.
A giant swan flies to the right on extended wings. The bird is ridden by a youthful male who holds a single rein attached to the partly-opened beak of the swan.
Four birds fly on extended wings right of the giant swan. Three birds are very small; the fourth is fairly large and has a prominent forked tail.
Two birds fly through the sky on extended wings between line 18 and the snake below. The bird on the right may have a forked tail.

A giant snake glides along the ground, probably moving to the right. Its mouth is open and its multi-colored scales and forked tongue are clearly pictured. At least one horn extends horizontally back from its head. The snake's body on the left forms a single loop and, further to the left, a single tail in this, the second state of the plate.
The green coloring below the snake suggests grass with a small plant with spiky leaves far right.

A youthful and muscular nude male rides on the swan's back. The figure's legs are spread apart and they dangle on each side of the swan's back just in front of its wings. The youth's hair is blown to the left by the onward flight of the bird. The figure looks back to the left, away from the direction of flight, and braces himself with his right arm. His left arm is raised horizontally and he holds in his left hand a rein attached to the swan's beak. This figure has sometimes been identified as Boston's Angel, although the reason for this may be nothing more than the fact that he is named in the text immediately above the figure (line 4).

A nude child, perhaps female, rides on the back of the snake nearest his head. She holds in her raised left hand a pair of reins attached to the snake's mouth. Her legs are together; her right arm is at her side or behind her back and braced on the snake's back. She looks to the right; her long hair trails to the left.

A nude child, probably male, rides on the back of the snake. His legs are spread apart. He braces himself with his left arm and may be holding onto the snake with his left hand. He reaches back with his right hand to hold the hand of the child or infant to the left.

A very young nude child or infant of uncertain gender rides on the snake's back nearest its tail. He or she faces to the right and raises his or her right arm to hold hands with the child further to the right. His hair may be curly.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several motifs follow the end of line 9 of the text. These are, from left to right, a stick figure with arms raised horizontally and striding to the left; a vine, perhaps with leaves, on which the figure walks; a vine with a loop, extending upward from the "d" of "commanded" in the line below; a mammal of some sort (a horse or fox?) with a bushy tail, running or leaping to the left; a vine extending from the "h" of "what" in line 10; and a series of swirls that may represent vines. Three birds fly above "the energies" (line 12); two fly above "and generosity" (line 13). Many letters bear vine-line extensions; those at the beginning of lines 2 and 14 contain loops, as does the vine extending above "& the" (line 14). The vine arching over "frowns" (line 7) may bear small leaves. There is a detached vine above "abstinence & wraps" (line 17).

At the end of line 9 of the text, and right of the human figure, a mammal of some sort, perhaps a horse or fox with a bushy tail, runs or leaps to the left.

The motifs following line 9 include three vines, one between the man and the animal extending from the "d" of "commanded" in line 10, one extending from the "h" of "what" in line 10, and the largest above the last three words of line 10. All contain loops.
Three birds fly above "the energies" (line 12); two fly above "and generosity" (line 13).

Many letters bear vine-line extensions; those at the beginning of lines 2 and 14 contain loops, as does the vine extending above "& the" (line 14). The vine arching over "frowns" (line 7) may bear small leaves. There is a detached vine above "abstinence & wraps" (line 17).

lg.l: Fiery the Angels rose, & as they rose deep thunder roll'd
Around their shores; indignant burning with the fires of Orc
And Bostons Angel cried aloud as they flew thro' the dark
night,
He cried; Why trembles honesty and like a murderer,
Why seeks he refuge from the frowns of his immortal station,
Must the generous tremble & leave his joy, to the idle: to
the pestilence!
That mock him? who commanded this, what God! what Angel!
To keep the gen'rous from experience till the ungenerous
Are unrestraind performers of the energies of nature;
Till pity is become a trade, and generosity a science,
That men get rich by, & the sandy desart is giv'n to the strong
What God is he, writes laws of peace, & clothes him in a tempest
What pitying Angel lusts for tears, and fans himself with sighs
What crawling villain preaches abstinence & wraps himself
In fat of lambs? no more I follow, no more obedience pay.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although containing considerable text, the plate is treated as a full-page design. Lower left, an old man enters a tomb. The post and lintel doorway, very probably built of stones, makes the tomb look like the entrance to a mine shaft. The lintel is extended, through hand coloring, into lines 13-16. The heavy wooden door is partly open, revealing within darkness and, lower left, either another stone or perhaps the edge of a bier. The old, bearded man wears a heavy gown; his prominent left foot can be seen under the hem. He faces, and is probably walking, to the left—into the tomb. He is bent over and leans on a crutch held in his left hand and propped beneath his left armpit. His hair appears to be blown by a wind from right to left, and hence towards the tomb entrance. To the right of the tomb is the trunk of a massive tree with a root extending along the ground to the right. The tree apparently continues behind the tomb and then grows above it, where we see more of the trunk, one large, leafless branch that arches over the text, and the leaves from another branch. Behind and to the right of the lower trunk of the tree is a form that is probably another tree trunk. Further to the right below the text is a dark and stormy sky with heavy clouds. A few vague forms on the horizon may be trees. Green coloring in the foreground suggests grass.

component.illusobjdesc: An old, bearded man wearing a heavy gown walks to the left and into the entrance to a tomb. His prominent left foot can be seen under the hem of his garment. He is bent over and leans on a crutch held in his left hand and propped beneath his left armpit. His hair appears to be blown by a wind from right to left, and hence towards the tomb entrance.
Small shadows extend to the left from the old man's left foot and crutch.

The old man enters a tomb. The post and lintel doorway, very probably built of stones, makes the tomb look like the entrance to a mine shaft. There are slight indications of a large hinge on the door just above the figure's back.
Within the tomb, lower left, we can see what may be another building stone or perhaps the corner of a bier.
To the right of the large tree trunk next to the tomb is another form with bold hatching lines. This is probably another tree trunk.
The distant view on the lower right side of the plate shows a dark and stormy sky with heavy clouds.

To the right of the tomb is the trunk of a massive tree with a root extending along the ground to the right. The tree apparently continues behind the tomb and then grows above it, where we see more of the trunk, one large, leafless branch that arches over the text, and the leaves from another branch.
A few odd forms on the horizon may be a clump of trees.
Green coloring in the foreground suggests grass.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several vegetative forms decorate the text. The most prominent are the vine (or perhaps a worm?) descending from the first letter of the first line; two vines between lines 7 and 9; and a vine or worm extending from the last letter of "its" in line 13, very close to the right margin of the plate. The extension of the final letter of "cried" (line 2) forms a loop; other vegetative forms appear above "rending" (line 2), above the second ampersand in line 10, as an extension of the first letter in line 11, and above "furnace" in line 16.

lg.l: So cried he, rending off his robe & throwing down his scepter
In sight of Albions Guardian, and all the thirteen Angels
Rent off their robes to the hungry wind, & threw their golden scep-
-ters
Down on the land of America, indignant they descended
Headlong from out their heav'nly heights, descending swift as
fires
Over the land; naked & flaming are their lineaments seen
In the deep gloom, by Washington & Paine & Warren they stood
And the flame folded roaring fierce within the pitchy night
Before the Demon red, who burnt towards America,
In black smoke thunders and loud winds rejoicing in its
terror
Breaking in smoky wreaths from the wild deep. & gath'ring thick
In flames as of a furnace on the land from North to South

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains considerable text, the pictorial image is treated as a full-page design showing the surface and bottom of the sea. The gray-green tinting of the text area makes it appear to be part of the water. Above the text, the limp body of a nude female lies supine on a stony shore, with her legs on the right extending into the waves of the sea. Her head is bent back and her long hair descends below, as does her dangling right arm. She is probably dead, perhaps from drowning. A plant with spiky leaves and a vine grow left of the woman's head. A large bird, very probably an eagle, is perched on her right upper leg. The eagle's wings are extended and his curved beak seems to be thrust into the woman's abdomen. The bird may be eating the corpse; indeed, a triangular form below his beak may be a piece of her flesh. The sky behind the bird is filled with clouds; the sea on the right (perhaps the Atlantic, named several times in the text) is stormy. Below the text we see the dark waters of the deep and the bottom of the sea. Upon it lies supine a nude male, with his knees bent slightly and his left arm at his side. His body is emaciated and rigid; he is no doubt dead, probably from drowning. We can see his ribs and his fingers look skeletal, perhaps because the sea creatures around him have been eating his flesh. These include one large fish and two small ones, all with their mouths open. A sea snake coils itself around the man's legs; another snake hovers above his chest. Five much smaller fish appear immediately below the text and in the right margin following lines 18 and 19. Below the man, on the floor of the sea, are two further sea snakes or worms. Near the lower right corner is a large, spiral shell, probably a whelk (common to the Atlantic). In the far lower right corner is a minimally-representational form that may be another shell. Vegetation rises in the left margin of the text almost touching the female figure on the rocky shore. This vegetation may be seaweed. The twisted lines include, left of lines 6-9 of the text, a snake with open mouth.

component.illusobjdesc: The limp body of a nude female lies supine on a rocky shore, with her legs on the right extending into the waves of the sea. Her head is bent back and her long hair descends below, as does her dangling right arm. She is probably dead, perhaps from drowning. The eagle perched on her body may be eating her flesh. Her right breast is prominent.

A nude male lies supine on the floor of the sea. His knees are bent slightly and his left arm is at his side. His body is emaciated and rigid; he is no doubt dead, probably from drowning. We can see his ribs and his fingers look skeletal, perhaps because the sea creatures around him have been eating his flesh. A sea snake is entwined around and binds his legs.
A plant with spiky leaves and a vine grow left of the woman's head.

A large bird, very probably an eagle, is perched on the right upper leg of the nude female. The bird's body faces forward, but its head is turned to the left. We can see one of his talons on her leg. The eagle's wings are extended and his curved beak seems to be thrust into the woman's abdomen. The bird may be eating the corpse; indeed, a triangular form below his beak may be a piece of her flesh.
Five small fish swim to the left just below line 19 and in the right margin following lines 18 and 19. A few have scales.

Two fish, one very large, swim to the right above the male corpse. A smaller fish swims to the left above the corpse's head. All three fish have their mouths open; the largest has teeth. They may be feeding on the dead body. All bear slight indications of scales.
A sea snake swims above the male corpse. The snake's mouth is slightly open. Its tail suggests a spiral.
A sea snake coils itself around the legs of the male corpse. The snake's mouth is slightly open.
Two sea snakes or worms rest on the ocean's floor below the man.

The wavy line left of lines 6-9 in the text is a snake with two loops in its body and facing to the right with mouth open. The snake's body is intertwined with the flag or vine extending from the first letter in line 8.
The spiral shell near the lower right corner of the plate may be from a whelk. However, the shell looks empty, and thus the whelk has died.
Vegetation—probably seaweed—grows up the left margin of the text. These vine-line plants include at least one loop.
The upper body of the female corpse rests on the stony shore of the sea.
The sky is filled with stormy clouds.
The sea—perhaps the Atlantic (frequently named in the text)—is filled with storm-tossed waves.
The surface of the dark water below the text shows indications of waves.
The gray-green coloring of the text area makes it look like part of the sea extending from its surface to the bottom.
The minimally-representational form in the far lower right corner of the plate may be a shell.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text area contains several representational motifs, mostly vines. The first letter of the first word in line 3 sprouts into two vines, one with a flower or leaf at its termination (on the left) and one with two loops (on the right). The final letter of "England" in line 3 grows into a vine with one loop. Between lines 4 and 6 is a row of vines, some with leaves. Sitting on one such vine, just right of the word "cry" (line 5), is a small figure with legs spread, left arm raised horizontally, and right arm raised at 45 degrees (assuming that the figure is facing forward, which seems likely). Two large leaves complete this row of motifs; a worm or caterpillar rises above the leaf on the left. The first letter in line 8 extends into a looping vine. A vine extends from the last letter of "all," end of line 8. A butterfly or bird flies at the end of line 6; another bird may be represented by the similar shape just above the right tip of the large leaf above the first bird. A vine, possibly with a leaf, extends from the first letter in line 16.

component.illusobjdesc: To the right of the word "cry" in line 5 of the text, carried over to its own line, a small figure sits on a vine with legs spread apart, left arm raised horizontally, and right arm raised at 45 degrees (assuming that the figure is facing forward, which seems likely).

The first letter in line 3 sprouts into two vines. The vine on the left terminates in a flower or leaf; the vine on the right forms two loops. The first letter in line 8 extends into a looping vine. The flag or vine extending from the first letter in line 9 is intertwined with the body of the snake in the margin.
The last letter of "England" in line 3 grows into a vine with a single loop.
The space between lines 4 and 6 of the text is filled with vine-like forms, some including leaves. Two large leaves end this group, close to the right margin of the plate.
The last word in line 8 of the text ("all") terminates in a vine extending horizontally to the right margin of the plate.
A butterfly bird flies at the end of line 6; another bird may be represented by the similar shape just above the right tip of the large leaf above the first bird.
