A vine, possibly with a leaf, extends from the first letter in line 16.

lg.l: -vene
What time the thirteen Governors that England sent con-
In Bernards house; the flames coverd the land, they rouze they
cry
Shaking their mental chains they rush in fury to the sea
To quench their anguish; at the feet of Washington down fall'n
They grovel on the sand and writhing lie. while all
The British soldiers thro' the thirteen states sent up a howl
Of anguish; threw their swords & muskets to the earth & ran
From their encampments and dark castles seeking where to hide
From the grim flames; and from the visions of Orc; in sight
Of Albions Angel; who enrag'd his secret clouds open'd
From north to south, and burnt outstretchd on wings of wrath cov'ring
The eastern sky, spreading his awful wings across the heavens;
Beneath him rolld his num'rous hosts, all Albions Angels camp'd
Darkend the Atlantic mountains & their trumpets shook the valleys
Arm'd with diseases of the earth to cast upon the Abyss,
Their numbers forty millions, must'ring in the eastern sky.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Most of the design appears between lines 10 and 11 of the text, but the roots of the large tree descend to the lower margin and its branches extend to the top. Thus, one must view the entire plate to see all elements of the design. Under the arching and leafless branches of this tree sits a figure, probably female. Immediately behind her may be the trunk of a second large tree. She is nude except for a long scarf she wears over her head; it trails on the ground to the right. Her legs are spread apart and bent at the knees, with her lower legs and feet drawn up near her thighs. She looks to the left toward the second figure in the design. Her left arm is braced next to her torso, with the left hand on the ground. Her right arm is extended horizontally, with the palm of her right hand facing down and her fingers (except for her downward-pointing thumb) pointing towards the other figure. She may be a sibyl or priestess. Between her legs is a coiled snake, with its head also directed at the second figure. The snake's mouth is open and its forked tongue is prominent. To the left is a young male with curly hair. He wears either a short gown or tights. He is seated on the ground, with his legs extended to the left and his upper body raised and twisted so that he faces right and looks toward the other figure. His hands are together in an attitude of prayer or supplication. His elbows are propped on a stack of two large books (or a tablet and a book on top). He may be a student or acolyte of the priestess. The sky behind the figures is filled with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: A giant tree grows near the center right margin of the plate. Its bare branches ascend in the right margin to the top of the plate; its twisted roots descend to the bottom of the plate. Other leafless branches arch to the left over the two human figures.
The trunk of a second large tree may be the form immediately behind the back of the seated figure with the snake.

A figure, probably female, sits beneath the overhanging limb of the large tree. She is nude except for a long scarf she wears over her head; it trails on the ground to the right. Her legs are spread apart and bent at the knees, with her lower legs and feet drawn up near her thighs. She looks to the left toward the second figure in the design. Her left arm is braced next to her torso, with the left hand on the ground. Her right arm is extended horizontally, with the palm of her right hand facing down and her fingers (except for her downward-pointing thumb) pointing towards the other figure. She may be a sibyl or priestess. Between her legs is a coiled snake, with its head also directed at the second figure.

A young male with curly hair sits on the ground. He wears either a short gown or tights. His legs extend to the left and his upper body is raised and twisted so that he faces right and looks toward the other figure. His hands are together in an attitude of prayer or supplication. His elbows are propped on a stack of two large books (or a tablet and a book on top). He may be a student or acolyte of the priestess or sibyl on the right.
The young male has his arms propped on two books—or a tablet and a book on top.
A bit of green tinting below and to the left of the youth suggests grass.
A snake coils itself between the legs of the seated woman. Its head points to the left; its mouth is open and its forked tongue is prominent.
Clouds fill the sky behind the two figures.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A fish or legless dragon with scaly skin faces left with open mouth. From its mouth issues a tongue of fire. A crest, like a dorsal fin, decorates its back. Blue wash just above the lower edge of the plate suggests sky or water.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A line of motifs appears above line 2. From left to right, these are a hovering figure facing right with at least one arm raised horizontally, a vine with leaves and perhaps a grain tassel, a cluster of vines and leaves, a bird flying upward on extended wings, a vine with one loop, a human figure, perhaps gowned and facing left with one arm raised horizontally, and finally two vines or slender leaves. At the end of line 3 is a vine with one loop. In line 6, a vine with loops and one leaf grows from the final letter of "as." In line 8, a vine with two loops grows from the second letter of "above." Another looped vine grows from the "s" of "as," line 10. A flag-like extension of the final letter of "earth" (line 16) extends over the word; another flag or leaf hovers vertically at the end of line 17. There is a row of representational forms between lines 17 and 18. These are, from left to right, a vine with loops, another vine, a bird flying upwards on extended wings, and a long vine with loops descending at the ends of lines 18-19.

component.illusobjdesc: A hovering figure, facing to the right and with at least one arm raised horizontally, appears above the second and third words in line 2. She or he may be wearing a gown that forms a curled tail. The figure may be holding something in his or her extended hand.

A small figure, facing to the left and with one arm raised horizontally, hovers above the words "drawn out" in line 2. The figure's legs are probably spread apart. Wisps of drapery below the figure suggest a gown, although this may only be a leaf below the figure.
A bird flies upward on extended wings above "armies" in line 2.
A bird flies upward on extended wings above "lost" in line 18.
The interlinear decorations above line 2 includes several vines. The vine above "stood" includes a loop, a leaf, and perhaps a grain tassel. The cluster above "view'd" includes leaves.
A vine with a single loop follows line 3.
A vine with four loops and a single leaf grows from the second letter of "as" in line 6.
A vine with two loops grows from the second letter of "above" in line 8 of the text. A vine with a single loop extends from the second the "s" of "as," line 10.
A flag-like extension of the final letter of "earth" (line 16) extends over the word; another flag or leaf hovers vertically at the end of line 17.

lg.l: In the flames stood & view'd the armies drawn out in the sky
Washington Franklin Paine & Warren Allen Gates & Lee:
And heard the voice of Albions Angel give the thunderous command;
His plagues obedient to his voice flew forth out of their clouds
Falling upon America, as a storm to cut them off
As a blight cuts the tender corn when it begins to appear.
Dark is the heaven above, & cold & hard the earth beneath;
And as a plague wind fill'd with insects cuts off man & beast;
And as a sea o'erwhelms a land in the day of an earthquake;
Fury! rage! madness! in a wind swept through America
And the red flames of Orc that folded roaring fierce around
The angry shores, and the fierce rushing of th' inhabitants together;
The citizens of New-York close their books & lock their chests;
The mariners of Boston drop their anchors and unlade;
The scribe of Pensylvania casts his pen upon the earth;
The builder of Virginia throws his hammer down in fear.
Then had America been lost, o'erwhelm'd by the Atlantic,
And Earth had lost another portion of the infinite,
But all rush together in the night in wrath and raging fire
The red fires rag'd! the plagues recoil'd! then rolld they back
with fury

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the upper left margin of the plate, a gowned figure, probably female, sits on the ground with her knees drawn up and her upper body and head leaning forward at a sharp angle. Her body faces right in this very contracted posture; her face is covered by her right knee. She may be mourning or sunk into despair. To the right of her is a plant with leaves and perhaps a flower at its top. To the left of the figure is a tree entwined with a vine. The tree apparently has long, slender leaves on its drooping branches. Above the figure, near the top left corner of the plate, a bird is either perching on the tree or flying upward on extended wings.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Near the middle of the left margin of the plate, we see a female figure from behind. Her arms, raised vertically, vegetate into vines or the limbs of trees; her feet are becoming roots. This transformation suggests the classical myth of Daphne. The green coloring on her body may signify tights or perhaps simply her vegetative character. Her legs are together and she faces to the right. The vegetation or limb extending from her right arm bears two figures: a seated adult, probably female, facing left and holding a child or infant who stands on her lap. Left of the Daphne-figure's left leg is another small figure, probably a female child. This figure faces up and reaches up with at least her right arm. This arm may be vegetating, as with the major figure. The green coloring on her body may signify tights or simply her vegetative nature. Left of this small figure is a vine with one loop.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Five nude female figures appear in flames in the design below the text. On the left, a female with legs slightly spread appears to be hovering in the flames or rising through them. Her arms are at her side; her long hair cascades over both shoulders. She is facing up and to the left. In the middle of the design is a group of three embracing females. The largest sits or squats, facing right but with her head lowered. She has long hair. We cannot see her face or arm positions. In her lap lies another nude female embracing the seated figure around her waist with her left arm, raised horizontally. Her body is twisted and her face is also hidden. The right-most figure in the group is facing forward; her face is covered by her long hair. She may be sitting or standing with a slight bend in her legs. Her left arm is extended horizontally. To the right of this group is another nude female in an extremely contracted posture, facing left. Her legs are drawn up with her knees to her chest. Her upper body leans forward over her raised knees and her left arm partly encircles her lowered head and long hair. Between the ascending figure on the left and the group of three females is a large grape leaf, a spiraling grape vine, and a large cluster of grapes. Above the group of three is another spiraling grape vine. The fires may be both the "flames of Orc" (line 14) and the "fires of hell" (line 18); the dark coloring at the tips of the flames suggests smoke.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text includes, between its lines and in the right margin, a great many interlinear motifs. Most of these take the form of vines or other vegetation; only the most significant of these will be recorded here. Above the second word ("Albions") in line 2, a bird flies upward on extended wings. The first letter of the first word in line 3 grows into a vine, perhaps with leaves. Line 4 is preceded by a horse running or leaping to the left. Following "Bristols" (line 4) are the following, reading left to right: a vine with a standing figure facing left, perhaps looking at a very small figure looking right with arms raised horizontally; a vine with a seated figure facing right; a flock of birds; a vine with perhaps a dog standing on it, facing left (and barking at the birds?); a vine with a standing figure facing left with at least one arm raised horizontally; a small bird and a large bird (an eagle?) flying upward; a tree trunk with one bare branch; a figure striding to the left, at least one arm raised vertically, holding something (perhaps a child?) in his or her raised hand. Two birds fly on extended wings above "And cast" in line 8. Following the word "mail," at the end of line 7, is another series of very small motifs. These are, from left to right: a leafless tree; a minimally representational form that may be a figure sitting on the ground with one arm propping up the upper body; two figures facing each other, perhaps coming together to embrace or to fight; a vine with one leaf; a vine with two loops and one leaf; a vine-like form with a figure above it, striding and facing to the left with at least one arm raised horizontally; a vine bearing, and arching over, a figure lying on it and facing left. Following line 9 is a vine, growing from the second letter of "chattering" in line 10, and a hovering figure, with legs spread, facing to the left and holding to his or her mouth (and thus playing?) a trumpet or horn of some sort. A vine with two loops extends to the left from the first letter of "hills," line 13. At the end of line 13, a twisting vine appears above the final word ("sky"). A tassel of grain grows from the final letter of "sky." Between lines 13 and 14 are several motifs. From left to right these are a vine with two loops growing from the first letter of "The" at the beginning of line 14; a very small figure striding to the right, with at least one arm raised horizontally, on top of the first letter of the first word in line 14; two vines, one with two loops; a small bird flying; a seated human figure with knees bent, at least one arm raised horizontally, and facing to the left; a vine with leaves growing from the "d" of "winds" in line 14; a vine or grain tassel growing from the first letter of "driven" in line 14; and a bird flying on extended wings above "flames" in line 14. A vine, with flowers or leaves, descends from the last letter of "scales," line 22 of the text. Birds fly on extended wing above "spirits" and "dead pining," line 26 of the text. Above "bonds of" in the same line, a stag runs or leaps to the left. A bird—or perhaps a moth—flies at the end of the line. A vine-like form with one loop connects the last letters of lines 25 and 29.

lg.l: On Albions Angels: then the Pestilence began in streaks of red
Across the limbs of Albions Guardian, the spotted plague smote
Bristols
And the Leprosy Londons Spirit, sickening all their bands;
The millions sent up a howl of anguish and threw off their ham-
-merd mail,
And cast their swords & spears to earth, & stood a naked multitude.
Albions Guardian writhed in torment on the eastern sky
Pale quivring toward the brain his glimmering eyes, teeth chattering
Howling & shuddering his legs quivering; convuls'd each muscle & sinew
Sick'ning lay Londons Guardian. and the ancient miter'd York
Their heads on snowy hills, their ensigns sick'ning in the sky
The plagues creep on the burning winds driven by flames of Orc,
And by the fierce Americans rushing together in the night
Driven o'er the Guardians of Ireland and Scotland and Wales
They spotted with plagues forsook the frontiers & their banners seard
With fires of hell, deform their ancient heavens with shame & woe.
Hid in his caves the Bard of Albion felt the enormous plagues.
And a cowl of flesh grew o'er his head & scales on his back & ribs;
And rough with black scales all his Angels fright their ancient heavens
The doors of marriage are open, and the Priests in rustling scales
Rush into reptile coverts, hiding from the fires of Orc,
That play around the golden roofs in wreaths of fierce desire,
Leaving the females naked and glowing with the lusts of youth
For the female spirits of the dead pining in bonds of religion;
Run from their fetters reddening, & in long drawn arches sitting:
They feel the nerves of youth renew, and desires of ancient times.
Over their pale limbs as a vine when the tender grape appears

illustration.illusobjdesc: A giant figure, wearing a gown and probably female, crouches on the ground in an extremely contracted posture. Her legs are bent under her body and her upper body is bent forward at a sharp angle over her legs. She faces right but her head faces down; her face is covered by her right arm, bent at the elbow with the upper arm raised. Apparently, her hands are together in an attitude of prayer or supplication. Her long hair cascades below her right elbow and down the right margin of the text, perhaps transformed into a waterfall (as is strongly suggested by the blue coloring in this copy). Despair and crying are suggested by the figure; perhaps we are to think of the waterfall as her tears. The figure has been variously identified as a personification of Earth (given the presence of other figures on her body) and even as Urizen, in spite of the apparent gender. Seven figures stand or sit on the giant's body. On her head is a gowned and seated figure, facing right and holding (and apparently reading) a book or tablet. On her back are two figures, one standing and facing right. This apparently gowned figure holds a book or tablet in her or his right hand. Just to the right is a kneeling figure, with one leg extended back, and the right arm raised at 135 degrees. This figure may be looking up and supplicating or praying. Below these two figures, and standing on the giant figure's right upper thigh, is a tree with three branches (but no leaves). Standing and leaning against this tree is a (probably male) figure facing to the right. He wears a broad-brimmed hat and holds and plays a pipe. Further down the giant's thigh are a few forms that may be sheep lying (and sleeping?) on her body. Thus, the piper is probably a shepherd. Below the piper, a very small figure lies on the giant's calf, facing right. This too may be a shepherd, given the presence of a few forms to the right that may be lying (and sleeping?) sheep. Just to the left of the giant's right foot is an embracing couple. The figure most likely to be the female in this group is gowned and seated with at least one leg bent at the knee, head facing down, and left arm raised horizontally to embrace her companion. The man (wearing tights?) kneels on the ground, facing right, with his right arm extended at 45 degrees to touch the woman's left thigh. To the right of this couple, and standing on the ground just beneath the giant's lower leg, a stag runs or leaps to the right. The left portion of this design above the text is a forest of at least four leafless trees. Their trunks have anthropomorphic forms, underscored in this copy by the flesh-like coloring. We can also see some of their roots near the left margin; one such root extends left of lines 2-10 in the left margin. The ground near both margins descends over cliffs.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The tailpiece for this final plate is an intertwined pattern of vegetation. It includes two large flower buds (right and left, probably roses), thorny branches from which the buds grow, several smaller flowers (right and left), several vines, and a snake facing to the right with its mouth open and a prominent forked tongue. "FINIS" in white lines is inscribed on the snake's body. There are also two human figures. One stands (and perhaps walks) just below the serpent's head. The figure faces right and has at least one arm raised at 45 degrees. The other figure appears just right of the large flower on the left. This figure is probably standing, facing to the left, and may have at least one arm raised horizontally.

Just beneath line 24, three flowers grow at the ends of branches or vines on the same plant. The two flowers on the left, one with a spiky shape, appear below the word "flames." The flower on the right appears under the words "heavens, &." There would appear to be at least three more spiky flowers in this copy.

Several vines are intertwined with other vegetation and the snake in the design. Independent of this group are vines, perhaps bearing flowers or leaves, in the right and left bottom corners of the plate.

lg.l: Over the hills, the vales, the cities, rage the red flames fierce;
The Heavens melted from north to south; and Urizen who sat
Above all heavens in thunders wrap'd, emerg'd his leprous head,
From out his holy shrine, his tears in deluge piteous
Falling into the deep sublime! flag'd with grey-brow'd snows
And thunderous visages, his jealous wings wav'd over the deep;
Weeping in dismal howling woe he dark descended howling
Around the smitten bands, clothed in tears & trembling shudd'ring cold.
His stored snows he poured forth, and his icy magazines
He open'd on the deep. and on the Atlantic sea white shiv'ring.
Leprous his limbs, all over white, and hoary was his visage.
Weeping in dismal howlings before the stern Americans
Hiding the Demon red with clouds & cold mists from the earth;
Till Angels & weak men twelve years should govern o'er the strong;
And then their end should come, when France reciev'd the Demons light.
Stiff shudderings shook the heav'nly thrones! France Spain & Italy,
In terror view'd the bands of Albion, and the ancient Guardians
Fainting upon the elements, smitten with their own plagues
They slow advance to shut the five gates of their law-built heaven
Filled with blasting fancies and with mildews of despair
With fierce disease and lust, unable to stem the fires of Orc;
But the five gates were consum'd, & their bolts and hinges melted
And the fierce flames burnt round the heavens, & round the abodes of
men
FINIS The word "FINIS" was etched in white line in the tail of the serpent at the bottom of the plate. In some other copies of *America*, such as Copies O and M, the word has been obscured by color.
